author: Dave Eckert, Assignment Editor
title: Royals home field secured, now match-ups matter
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - Now that the Royals have secured home field advantage throughout the playoffs, their attention will turn to potential playoff match-ups.
The Royals will host the winner of the Wild Card game between the Yankees and Astros in the American League Divisional Series. Games one, two, and, if necessary, five will be played on the Royals home turf in Kauffman Stadium.
How important is that? Well, consider the Royals lost all six games they played against Houston and New York on the road.
There are many factors that enter into that 0-6 record, including the Astros' and Yankees' stadiums.
The new Yankee Stadium is just 314 feet down the right field line, so the Bronx Bombers load up with lefties who can pull it down the line and over the wall.
Houston's Minute Maid Park, meantime, has a short left field, only 315 feet. The Astros lineup is packed with righties who pull the ball over the short porch in left.
There are other home field quirks too, like the hill in the middle of dead center in Houston. Ask Lorenzo Cain how much fun that is. Cain tripped on the hill and smashed into the center field wall while tracking a fly ball during one of the Royals losses there earlier this year.
While the Yankees and Astros build their roster to suit their ballparks, so do the Royals. The Royals play in spacious Kauffman Stadium. They're roster is loaded with pitchers who induce fly balls and outfielders who routinely chase them down.
The Royals are 4-2 against the Yanks and Astros at Kauffman this year. That's not perfect, but it's way better than 0-6 on the road.
Yeah, home field advantage is really important, especially for the Royals.
Kansas City will find out who'll they'll be playing when the Astros and Yankees square off on Tuesday.
